text: So this customer is from the insurance domain and they deal in the insurance product like life insurance, health insurance, and general insurance.
Their core competency is not managing the infrastructure
and that's why they had outsourced their IT operations to multiple vendors
who are responsible for building and maintaining application as per the business need.
So the customer wanted to move to the cloud because of the three key problems they were facing.
The first one was a scalability challenge with their application, which is a customer onboarding application,
which was either slowing down or showing some outage because of the non-scalability of the on-prem infrastructure.
The second key problem was the monolith architecture of the application.
So their underwriting application had some manual steps, and they wanted to build that using the native cloud technology
so that they can automate the overall process end to end and reduce the policy issuance time,
which was actually taking more than 12 minutes, which was not acceptable by their customers.
The third problem was data. So 200+ applications were generating huge sets of data which was not actually used anywhere else.
They wanted us to come up with an approach of a data lake strategy, where this data can be leveraged for building the insights
and also building machine learning model on which they can build innovative products for their end customer.
In the first phase, we worked closely with the customer and it was decided to do a lift and shift of their existing client onboarding and underwriting application
to run on EC2 instances with custom AMI, including their applications and dependencies, originally with auto scaling.
This allowed them to run the application on the cloud at scale, while lowering the cost and maintenance for their machines.
Phase two was exactly the moving away from legacy architecture
and build transformed applications into modern cloud native architecture.
In terms of scaling, they started leveraging CloudFront to deliver static web content in a fast and secure manner,
while building new set of microservices that are deployed in front of containers on ECS.
If we take an example of a customer onboarding application which is used by their end user during the policy issuance process,
it used to take around 12 minutes and even more, which is not acceptable and impacting the overall customer experience.
To improve this overall cycle, they need to scale the application as per the market demand and the peak load
and that is also only possible when they will deploy the application on auto EC2 machines with auto scalability.
If the automation is built on top of that, that can reduce the overall policy issuance time from 12 minutes to two minutes,
which will significantly improve the overall customer experience.
FSI businesses generate a huge set of data, which is lying in silos on-prem without any use.
If this data is moved to the AWS Cloud and a centralized data lake can be built, insight can be generated out of that data
which can help businesses in making decisions
This data can also be used to build multiple machine learning models, predicting the behavior of the customer.
With that machine learning outcome, the customer can focus on building applications as per their customer need.
